webReference.description:
Liyuan Woo - Chief Financial Officer

With me on the call today is Andrew Stanleick, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Liyuan Woo, Chief Financial Officer of the Beauty Health Company.

With that, I will now turn the call over to Liyuan for a more detailed discussion of our first quarter performance.

Liyuan Woo

Liyuan, if I could just throw in one more question.
It's a technical one, but we're getting this question.
Could you walk through the timing of revenue recognition on the trade-ups?
It sounds like you had some essentially trade-up requests that you hadn't filled at the end of the quarter.
So just walk us through how the trade-up revenue recognition works and then how the costs flow through as well from a P&L timing perspective?

Liyuan Woo

Absolutely.

I'll start and then pass on to Liyuan.
To address the first part of your question.
So, as I stated earlier, we intentionally and planned the launch in mid-March to encourage as many of our providers to get on the SYNDEO system, especially those and we've talked before about who've recently purchased the elite system, but, of course, our ultimate goal is to get everyone on SYNDEO because it's data and consumer knowledge will ultimately drive further growth.

We had the promotion which we planned which finished at the end of March that drove very short-term demand, which will also go into Q2 and then that promotion stops over the rest of the year certainly and if we talk about the U.S. market where we've launched today, you'll see a more gradual roll out of the SYNDEO system.
So I'll pause there and hand over to Liyuan who can comment on the margin and we can return to your international question later.

Liyuan Woo

For the moment though, as Liyuan spoke to, we have built in the lockdown in our guidance, which we've given and confirmed for the rest of the year.

Liyuan Woo

Liyuan Woo(1)

Liyuan Woo joined bebe in August 2010 and currently serves as Principal Accounting Officer and Vice President Corporate Controller.
Prior to joining bebe, Ms. Woo held a Senior Manager position with the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche, LLP in its M&A Transaction Services Group from October 2004 through July 2010.
Ms. Woo is a Certified Public Accountant.

Francois Delepine, CFO of Venafi, a cybersecurity software company, attended the dinner and in an interview afterwards summed up Mr. Shenkman's assessment of the current role of the CFO by simply saying, "The job of the CFO is to be a problem solver and to find solutions," while Liyuan Woo, former CFO of Bebe Stores, an upscale fashion retailer, went a step further and likened the modern-day CFO's role to that of a "co-pilot to the CEO and other senior executives.

Ms. Woo had a theory about the CFO's more demanding job description: "Traditionally, the CFO has been seen as a very objective person who comes to the table from the rational side that deals with the numbers.

In an interview, Ms. Woo echoed this: "No longer is the day where you can just repeat what you learned from the past.

webReference.description:
Robin O'Connell, Liyuan Woo and Jim Spencer Join Digiliti Money's Board

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn. - August 23, 2016 - Digiliti Money, Inc. (OTCQB: CAFN), a leading mobile FinTech provider, has appointed three new highly qualified independent directors to the board: Robin O'Connell, Liyuan Woo and Jim Spencer, effective August 17, 2016.

Liyuan Woo was most recently Chief Financial Officer of bebe stores, inc., a publically held global fashion company, where she helped guide the company through critical restructurings and a turnaround plan, and helped improve bottom-line results by more than $30 million in fiscal year 2015.
Ms. Woo also spearheaded bebe's global expansion, helping to grow the company's international and wholesale market.
Prior to bebe, she was Senior Manager at Deloitte, a big four advisory firm, where she led and managed deal teams for Deloitte's M & A Transaction Services practice.
In that role, she advised private equity firms and strategic buyers for financial services, technology and other industries for deals ranging from $500 million to $20 billion.
Ms. Woo has a BA in Accounting from Bentley University, and previously held a CPA license for the states of California and Massachusetts.
She previously served on the board as Treasurer for Dress for Success San Francisco, a non-profit organization assisting underprivileged women.
Ms. Woo also received recognition by San Francisco Business week in 2014 and 2015 as one of the Most Influential Women in Business in the Bay Area.
webReference.title: Press Releases :: Digiliti Money Welcomes Three New Independent Directors :: Digiliti Money

personBiography: "Liyuan has served as the CFO, EVP since September 2020 and oversees all finance and operations aspects of the company. Liyuan has more than 24 years of experience building and creating infrastructure to enable aggressive global scaling, while promoting sustainable profitability. Prior to The Beauty Health Company, Liyuan was the COO & CFO of The VOID, a highly rated virtual reality brand introducing consumers to fully immersive, location-based, hyper-reality experiences. Throughout her career, Liyuan has provided leadership to both growth oriented and turnaround situations. Prior to the VOID, Liyuan was the CFO, EVP at SharkNinja, a growth oriented multi-billion dollar consumer electronic product portfolio category creator focused on innovation and marketing. At SharkNinja, she was in charge of finance, capital raising and allocation, legal and strategic initiatives involving global expansion and M&A.\nPreviously, she served as a Director of Alix Partners and acted as CFO during Gymboree Group’s multi-billion dollar restructuring process. Liyuan also teamed up with other executive members in establishing the strategic plan, a supply chain hub in Asia as well as other international expansion efforts. Prior to that, she was the CFO of bebe stores, a publicly traded global multi-channel fashion brand. During her 6 years with bebe stores, she was responsible for all aspects of finance and operations. Liyuan started her career with the consulting firm Deloitte in its Mergers and Acquisitions Transaction Services and Financial Advisory functions. During her 13 years with Deloitte, she provided financial advisory services to public and private companies for M&A transactions, IPOs and growth initiatives. Since September 2021, Liyuan has also served on the board of Shawmut Design and Construction, a leading $1.5 billion national construction management firm."

Tiffiny Furdak

Senior Director of Global Product Operations at Rodan + Fields

Tiffiny is a Supply Chain and Product Operations Consultant and has spent the last twelve years of her career at Gap, Inc. in various leadership capacities.
Prior to retail, she held product management and marketing roles at at i2 Technologies (JDA) and led global strategic sourcing initiatives for General Motors.

Tiffiny is as an active member of the Year Up Bay Area Leadership Council.
Over the past five years, she helped to established Year Up corporate participation at Gap, Inc.
She continues to mentor Year Up students, speak to Year Up classes about career options, and leverage her background in retail to give specialized trainings in professional dress for the workplace.
She is inspired by the transformational work of the YUBA staff and in particular, the strength, dedication, and professionalism of the students who participate in the Year Up program.

She lives in San Francisco with her husband and four year old daughter.
Born and raised in Michigan, she enjoys running, yoga, wine, food, and traveling.
She recently joined the Advisory Board for the Northern California chapter of Junior Achievement.

ADAM MERCER - Southeast Corrections Technology Manager

ADAM MERCER - Southeast Corrections Technology Manager Picture

In the role of Southeast Corrections Technology Manager, Mr. Mercer works with internal and external teams to ensure that the needs of our current and potential customers are being met through Digital Solutions and Inmate Telephone's advanced technologies and services.
He works primarily in the states of Alabama, Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, North Carolina, South Carolina and Tennessee.

Mr. Mercer has worked in the corrections industry for over nine years.
Coupled with a degree in Computer Information Systems, Mr. Mercer is very familiar with the technology and software market.
In that time he has worked in, managed, or in some way been affiliated with areas such as Product Development, Database Administration, Account Management, Prepaid Services, Sales, and Technical Customer Support.
He has supported accounts nationally, though most recently his efforts have been concentrated on the Southeast region of the United States.

Mr. Mercer believes that his role is to work closely with the customer to understand their needs, how those needs compare to the existing technologies in use by each customer, and how DSI/ITI can provide solutions to fill those gaps today and into the future.

webReference.description:
Recently, Sport Clips added value to its support in the northeast market with the addition of Patti Carr as vice president of Operations.

Joining the team in August, Carr brings expansive expertise in operational support and almost three decades of experience across multiple franchise brands.
Along with a team of six coaches, comprised of five technical coaches and one operational coach, Carr helps team leaders in the northeast implement the brand's winning formula and maximize their revenue.

After a store has completed its first six months with the grand opening support team , support does not end there.
"Sport Clips provides team leaders with support that is ongoing and in perpetuity," explains Carr.

We are able to work one-on-one with stylists, as well as provide monthly classes for their continued development," explains Carr.

With so many years of working closely with franchisees, Carr understands what goes into creating a successful store.
"Follow the system.
It's tried and true, and it works.
Beyond that, you also must be able to recruit and retain quality team members," she states.
" Store culture is important to retention . Keep them motivated and keep communication open.
People don't just stay for the money, they stay when they feel valued and appreciated."

With a dynamic and expert support system in place, the northeast is poised for tremendous growth . Carr explains, "This is an emerging market for Sport Clips with the potential for exponential growth.
Brand awareness continues to grow.
There are exciting opportunities for someone to come in and scale."

Carr has worked with a variety of other franchise brands, so she has a unique perspective on what it takes to become a franchisee with Sport Clips.
" The selection process used to vet potential franchise candidates is unlike any I have seen in franchising.
Being so dedicated to franchisee success, the process is about really exploring whether this is a good fit, both ways.
Sport Clips takes the time to educate candidates.
Transparency is important."

Carr concludes, "This is a great company to be a part of.

As the website becomes part of a social marketing campaign later this year, the call-to-action placement for purchase and some language is likely to change, said Freeman.
However, the end goal will still be to prompt customers to discuss their results with a therapist on live chat, versus self-prescribe products they may not need.

"[Face Mapping] has been designed to create a 'wow' moment for the brand and provide an interesting talking point," said Freeman.

webReference.description: As Clinique's VP of global store design and merchandising Anthony Battaglia said "it is the end of 'do not touch'.
webReference.title: The Death of the Gatekeeper

webReference.description:
"When the brand introduced Clinique's Service as you like it concept in 2009, our goal was to reinvent the prestige beauty shopping experience, offering multiple levels of innovative service," explained Clinique's Anthony Battaglia, Vice President of Global Store Design and Visual Merchandising.
"We wanted consumers to engage and interact with the brand in a creative and welcoming environment.
The Experience Bar takes the consumer's experience one step further.
It's a modern evolution in product sampling that allows people to explore and interact with our products in a new and inviting way."

Mr. Battaglia informs that shoppers are first captivated by the colorful and visually impactful, appealing display.

"The self-guided skincare diagnostic tool has been a core part of Clinique's Service as you like it shopping model since inception," Mr. Battaglia shared.

"Our Consultants have told us that clients stop by because the installation is so 'eye-catching,' and all the bright colors and digital components invite shoppers to slow down to learn more about what Clinique has to offer," Mr. Battaglia shared.

According to Mr. Battaglia, the Experience Bar is intuitive for consumers, which allows Clinique Consultants to give shoppers the space to browse freely, but they are always available to support anyone who may have additional questions.

Mr. Battaglia also revealed that "overall, Clinique's Service as you like it model has changed the way Consultants do their job.
Consumers are encouraged to shop at their leisure, yet Consultants are always close by when someone needs assistance.
The Experience Bar has definitely helped engage consumers, and the results from the skincare diagnostic tool through the iPadï¿½ certainly verify the Consultants' beauty advice and expertise.
The Experience Bar and multi-language programmed iPadsï¿½ have allowed Consultants to cross language and communication barriers easily, ensuring a positive shopping experience.
Mr. Battaglia maintains that this new installation "is another tool to help Consultants build relationships and educate their clients on how Clinique can create healthy skin."

Ms. Zachary and Mr. Battaglia (r.) with Clinique's Jenny Canseco and Nile Mathias at the Experience Bar
Anthony Battaglia, Clinique's vice-president of of global store design and visual merchandising, says the idea is "to remind the customer: Our product is here to play with."

title: Vice President & General Counsel
personBiography: Mr. Bokota has served as HydraFacial’s VP & General Counsel since November 2020. Mr. Bokota has over 28 years of legal experience. He manages HydraFacial’s legal team and oversees all aspects of the Company’s global legal efforts. Prior to joining HydraFacial, Mr. Bokota worked for six years as the Division General Counsel for Spectrum Brands, Inc, managing global legal affairs for its Hardware & Home Improvement division. Spectrum Brands is a $3.5 B publicly traded consumer products company. Mr. Bokota has held various senior legal positions for public and privately held global companies. Prior to his in-house legal career, Mr. Bokota was a commercial litigator for 13 years, litigating and trying a wide variety of cases in state and federal court. Mr. Bokota received his A.B. magna cum laude in Government from Harvard University and his J.D. magna cum laude from Indiana University.

webReference.description:
Joan Nieman
Practice Manager
Joan was owner/operator of The Pet Resort in Oklahoma City for 12 years.
In 1994 she joined Best Friends Pet Care, Inc., the first chain of pet hotels in the US.
She became Director of Training for the then 12-store chain and was instrumental in developing its standards of care.
She served as District Manager and Regional Director while growing it to a 42-store 48 million dollar chain in 18 states.
In 2005 she joined the executive team as Vice President of Operations, overseeing five district directors and 42 field managers.

Joan has been a leader in the industry and served on the Board of Directors of the Pet Care Services Association, a national trade association, and also served as chairman of its Ethics Committee.
She is a licensed business consultant.

BY JOAN NIEMAN

Joan Nieman, Vice President of Operations for Best Friends Pet Care, has more than 30 years of experience in the pet care industry.
Prior to joining Best Friends in 1994, she owned and operated The Pet Resort in Oklahoma for a decade and has been active on industry associations, including serving on the board of the Pet Care Services Association.

I worked with Joan Nieman for over 19 years when I was Director of Grooming for Best Friends Pet Care, Inc.
Her people skills and operations expertise helped to grow Best Friends into a renowned multi-store chain.
Her mission was to insure that all facets of pet care within the chain were delivered standardly and effectively while maintaining sales growth and profits for the company.

webReference.description:
Markwins appoints Eric Weeks to president of sales for North America
Premium Beauty News
23 November 2020
Share:
Markwins appoints Eric Weeks to president of sales for North America

Markwins Beauty Brands has appointed Eric Weeks to the Executive Position of President of Sales and Revenue for North America-USA, Canada, and Mexico.
The new role provides Weeks the opportunity to drive the company's mission of an outside-in, consumers- and customers-first approach to business driven by effective customer service, communication, and information.

Eric Weeks

Eric Weeks

Weeks, who joined Markwins in 2001 has contributed in various sales and management roles within the company.
His nearly 20 years of experience at Markwins gives him unparalleled insight into the company's strategy and operations.
Weeks will continue to work closely with Markwins founder and CEO, Eric Chen.

Weeks is committed to spearheading a charge to develop and invigorate Markwins' pricing and promotional strategies, while working closely with the Executive Team and Brand Leadership on Marketing and Branding initiatives.
Additionally, he will facilitate an environment where recruitment, career enhancement, and retention of talent forms the cornerstone of Markwins' sales organization.

"I am sincerely grateful to Eric and Lina Chen to be given the opportunity to help the rest of the management team lead Markwins into the next phase of our journey in a post COVID environment," says Weeks.
webReference.title: Markwins appoints Eric Weeks to president of sales for North America

webReference.description:
Markwins Appoints Eric Weeks to President of Sales for North America

Eric Weeks, Markwins Beauty Brands President of Sales and Revenue for North America

CITY OF INDUSTRY, Calif., Nov. 19, 2020 /PRNewswire/ -- Markwins Beauty Brands ("Markwins" or the "Company"), has appointed Eric Weeks to the Executive Position of President of Sales and Revenue for North America-USA, Canada, and Mexico.
The new role provides Weeks the opportunity to drive the company's mission of an outside-in, consumers- and customers-first approach to business driven by effective customer service, communication, and information.

Weeks, who joined Markwins in 2001, is well-known and well-liked within the organization and has contributed in various sales and management roles since joining the company.
His nearly 20 years of experience at Markwins gives him unparalleled insight into the company's strategy and operations.
Weeks will continue to work closely with Markwins founder and CEO, Eric Chen.

Weeks is committed to spearheading a charge to develop and invigorate Markwins' pricing and promotional strategies, while working closely with the Executive Team and Brand Leadership on Marketing and Branding initiatives.
Additionally, he will facilitate an environment where recruitment, career enhancement, and retention of talent forms the cornerstone of Markwins' sales organization.

"I am sincerely grateful to Eric and Lina Chen to be given the opportunity to help the rest of the management team lead Markwins into the next phase of our journey in a post COVID environment," says Weeks.
"In addition to serving the greater company I hope to provide an enhanced conduit to both our consumers and customers through active listening and partnership."

During his spare time, Eric devotes time to his children, Elvis and Lola.
He loves baseball-when the Yankees are winning-and he swings the golf club with reckless abandon.

Kelly McIntosh has more than 20 years of progressive human resources leadership experience in such diverse industries as healthcare, financial services and distribution.
For the past twelve years, Kelly has served in senior management roles where she has been responsible for overseeing all aspects of human resources.
For the past six years, she has overseen human resources internationally, specifically in Eastern and Western Europe and India.
She has been instrumental in restructuring compensation and benefit programs, spearheading recruitment initiatives, and establishing an organizational development function that initiated a company-wide customer service campaign.
Kelly has served as a leadership coach in managing highly sensitive human resource issues and implemented an online open enrollment benefits program.
Kelly holds a Master's Degree in Human Resources Management.

personBiography:
We partnered with Courageous Co. to bring OPI’s global cross-functional team members together for an Innovation Workshop. Steve’s extensive track record developing innovation and gaining stakeholder buy in early in the development process made him the perfect choice for our project.  Steve spent substantial time with the project organizers weeks out from the event date to align on the process and participants to ensure we were able to address our objectives.
The session itself was done as a hybrid, with Steve leading the flow and moderation virtually from the UK and our team presenting and discussing live in CA. Steve did a great job to build in moments of connection and creativity throughout the process, and to keep the team focused on our needs. We were very happy with his ability to bring the different stake holders together to align on the top innovation directions.

webReference.description:
BBR10's keynote, Jan Lombardo, has more than 25 years of beauty industry experience as an executive for Estée Lauder and VP of sales for North America for Calvin Klein.
In 2009, she joined Go SMiLE, Inc. as VP of global sales and marketing, and in just three short years, was named president.

Jan Lombardo, president of Go SMiLE, Inc. discusses "Critical in Small Companies--How to Choose and Develop an Entire Team Invested in Company Success" at the BBR10 event
Jan Lombardo, president of Go SMiLE, Inc. discusses "Critical in Small Companies-How to Choose and Develop an Entire Team Invested in Company Success" at the BBR10 event

Lombardo discussed how creating and developing an entire team can lead to major success in small businesses.

In her roundtable discussion, she shared Go SMiLE's core competencies regarding employees: 1) They must be an expert in their field; 2) they must be able to mentor and train others; and 3) they need to be flexible, likable, and have a sense of humor.
"A workplace should be an enjoyable experience since you spend the majority of your time with your colleagues," she explained.
Lombardo also emphasized the importance of understanding the skills and loyalty of current employees, being extremely transparent with employees, and always remaining positive.

jan lombardo

Jan started working in the beauty industry over 25 years ago by selling behind the Estée Lauder counter, working her way up, and spending 18 years as an executive.
She became VP of Sales for North America at Calvin Klein Beauty before leaving in 2009 to join GO SMiLE, Inc. as the VP of Global Sales and Marketing.

In early 2012, Jan was named President of GO SMiLE, Inc.
She has created a team that can volley between being experts leading their departments and generalists giving input on all aspects of company development.
It is a team that has taken the company on an entirely new course of growth, vision and overall success.

Burrows likens the reception area to a high-end hotel, luxurious but with the durability to handle a large volume of traffic.

Gene Juarez VP of Facilities Susie Burrows created that all-around appeal through a design she calls New York-Loft-meets-the-Pacific-Northwest.

"With the numerous windows and the concrete floors, it has the rawness of a loft, but with refined elements and warmth brought through furnishings, paint, and tile," she says.

In the retail area, Burrows went with simple, white laminate shelving so the products are in the spotlight.

webReference.description:
Regis Corporation Announces the Additions of Andra Terrell and Jamie Suarez to Leadership Team

Andra Terrell joins the company as Senior Vice President, General Counsel, and Jamie Suarez is promoted to Senior Vice President, Merchandising & Education.

"Andra and Jaime are both leaders in their respective professions.

"What resonated most with me about Andra is how she leads with building and cultivating relationships," continued Mr. Doctor.

Most recently Ms. Terrell was Vice President, Deputy General Counsel and Assistant Secretary of Cajun Operating Company for the Church's Chicken® and Texas Chicken® brands.
She assisted with the launch of food delivery and order-ahead-pay ahead, as well as its global rebranding and technology efforts.

Ms. Terrell added, "I am thrilled to join Regis for the opportunity to help cement the relationship between Regis and its franchisees because we are better together.
I am a firm believer that companies working in concert with their franchisees are able to better serve customers and achieve sustainable results."

Ms. Terrell specializes in franchise law and brings more than 25 years of experience to Regis.
As the Assistant General Counsel - Franchise for Luxottica Retail, she served Pearle Vision® and other franchised eyewear brands, including Oakley® and Sunglass Hut®.
She was also the Assistant General Counsel for General Nutrition Centers, Inc., Franchise Counsel for Precision Tune Auto Care, Inc. and General Counsel of Decorating Den Systems, Inc.

Ms. Terrell received her Juris Doctorate from Howard University and her Bachelor of Arts degree in Natural Sciences and History of Science from The Johns Hopkins University.

Andra J. Terrell

Andra Terrell has been Assistant General Counsel - Franchise for Luxottica Retail at their corporate headquarters in Mason, Ohio since May 2005.
Prior to her work with Luxottica, Ms. Terrell served as the Assistant General Counsel for General Nutrition Centers, Inc., a Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania based franchisor of nutritional supplement retailers with over 4,200 locations worldwide from 1999-2005.
From September 1995 through March 1998 she was the General Counsel of Decorating Den Systems, Inc., an Easton, Maryland based franchisor of home decorating services with more than 500 franchises in the United States and Canada.
And from March 1998 through November 1998 she was Franchise Counsel for Precision Tune Auto Care, Inc., a Leesburg, Virginia based franchisor of auto care centers with 410 stores worldwide.

As a result, shopper-marketing efforts are increasingly gender-neutral rather than targeted for female shoppers, Ms. Sanchez said.

webReference.description:
Mariana Sanchez
Saatchi & Saatchi X - Mariana Sanchez

Saatchi & Saatchi X

Mariana Sanchez

This is Mariana Sanchez
Chief Strategy Officer

Throughout her career, Mariana's strategic leadership has helped shape the strategies, communications, and brand experiences of some of the world's most iconic and prestigious brands in and out of the store, and around the world.
After leading global communications for Crest for 7 years at Saatchi & Saatchi, Mariana joined Saatchi & Saatchi X 2 years ago to head our strategic capability.
Her innate curiosity leads her to find out what shoppers truly want and what they do... and why they do what they do, in order to meet or exceed their expectations and/or help influence their behavior.

It is with that spirit that Mariana oversees our Research & Discovery and Strategic Planning departments worldwide.
In her role, she helps guide the strategic direction of our work based on sound shopper understanding.
Leading the teams to find the strategic connections between the shopper insights, the retail environment, and the business objectives.

She is an award-winning talent with Effies, Cannes Lions, and Clios.
She has been a speaker at the IMI Conference and recently co-authored the Saatchi & Saatchi network thought leadership piece on the new value mind-set.

Mariana was born and raised in Mexico and was educated in Paris, France, where she started her career.
She has been based in the US for the past 15 years and has traveled extensively around the world.
This diverse cultural background and exposure to many cultures has helped her (and at times forced her!) to have more empathy and develop an ability to comprehend what people really want and a sensibility to grasp the nuances in what people say and do.

You can read more about Mariana here http://www.linkedin.com/profile?viewProfile=&key=7344864

webReference.description: AUCTION DONATION - Barb Grycz, Director of InSpa has graciously donated a spa package to our silent auction.

Barbara Grycz, manager of In Spa, is seeing more and more men coming to the spa for treatment.About 10 percent of the spa's clientele are men, she said."It used to be their wives and girlfriends who made appointments for them, but now men are coming by themselves," said Grycz.Eyebrow waxing, Grycz said, is increasingly popular among men.Personally, I appreciate the brow wax because it allows me to refer to the plural -- instead of just "my eyebrow." Grycz notes that the cultural shift has a lot to do with what is on TV (which reminds me, I can't forget to TiVo Will and Grace again).A new generation of men, Grycz said, are more comfortable with personal beauty care."The premise behind our spa is to make men feel more comfortable," said Grycz.

webReference.description:
"The Cynosure Apogee Elite [is] a dual-wavelength laser, so it has the capability of using one wavelength for our lighter skin types and a separated wavelength for our darker skin types," Morgan Wolf, a nurse practitioner at LaserAway, explains.

Relieved that I would be in good hands, I went ahead and scheduled my first appointment.
As with all other kinds of laser treatments, it's advised that you only shave the treatment area 24 hours prior (no tweezing or waxing) and stay away from tanning beds or self-tanners.
During my first visit, the nurse on-site administering the laser that day prepped my face with a makeup remover wipe to get rid of anything lingering on my skin's surface.
Then came an important safety precaution: a spot test.
"We do test pulses off to the side of the face just to double-check that everything looks good and that the energy is coming out properly - and then we watch the effect on the hair," says Wolf.

When lasers first rose to popularity, the original devices often had difficulty distinguish between one's hair follicles and the surrounding skin if the patient was dark-complected.
But in the years since the early aughts, the technology has advanced tremendously.
"We can actually adjust the parameters so that the laser just hits the melanin, which is generally darker in the hair follicle, and preserve that surrounding healthy skin tissue," explains Wolf.

Fast forward three sessions later, I've had nothing but great results thus far.

Since the beginning of this journey, I was told I'd require about seven to eight treatments in order to see a significant difference.
"On average, each person, regardless of skin type, [sees] about a 10 to 15 percent reduction [in hair growth] with each treatment.
Typically, if you're adding those up, the ideal outcome would be 70 to 90 percent reduction from when you started your treatments," says Wolf.
webReference.title: What Women of Color Should Know About Laser Hair Removal, From Someone

webReference.description:
Morgan Wolf, NP
National Director of Clinical Operations

Board certified Family Nurse Practitioner, Dr. Morgan Wolf, is the National Director of Clinical Operations, overseeing the team of Regional Clinical Directors company-wide.
She completed her Bachelor of Science in Nursing from Bloomsburg University of Pennsylvania.
She then went on to earn her Doctorate in Nursing Practice at the University of San Diego where she completed a dual program for Family Nurse Practitioner and Adult/Geriatric Nurse Practitioner.

Morgan has over 7+ years experience working in aesthetic dermatology with advanced skills and certification in facial rejuvenation, laser and light based treatments, body contouring, and aesthetic injectable education.
In 2018, she was selected to become an Allergan Medical Institute Trainer and Speaker for Facial Aesthetics.
She is also a member of the American Association of Nurse Practitioners (AANP), the American Nurses Association & ANA\California, and the California Association for Nurse Practitioners (CANP).

webReference.description:
Dr. Angela Murphy

We all know that sleep is vital to the rest and renewal of our body, but did you know that sleep problems affect the health and quality of life for up to 45% of the world's population?
In fact, missing just one night's sleep can impair the skin's ability to properly repair itself.
In this episode, Dermalogica's Dr. Angela Murphy discusses in depth what exactly happens to our skin while we sleep, and why it's so important to get your recommended rest.
She shares how getting enough sleep actually revs up your skin cells ensuring your skin is in its best possible shape for the next day.

webReference.description: Part of this continued sense of community is due to Garth Warner, 38, who assumed the role of regional vice president in January. "I would just like to broaden our reach,' Warner said. A father himself, Warner is especially on the lookout for groups that promote athletics and other extracurricular activities for young women, he said. "I do believe (athletics) are very important in the development of anyone, especially young women,' he said."They promote teamwork, partnering and preparing for the future.' Musical programs advocate much the same, he said. At age 22, Warner began his career with Avon in the operations department.Over the years, he has held a variety of positions, including division sales manager in Massachusetts and Philadelphia and regional sales director in Chicago. Some Avon outreach projects have been aimed at developing business skills in local residents. In 1999, Avon started small business training and development program through the Pasadena City College Community Development Center.Avon employees lecture on such issues as employer expectations, business Web site design, goal setting and how to run a retail business, according to the company. "It gives them a real-world look at how you run a business,' said Avon spokeswoman Stephanie DuPre. Avon employees also volunteer for organizations aimed at children. It is the responsibility of good "corporate citizens' to participate in such programs, Warner said. "I think from a business standpoint, we want to be the company that is most respected and most admired for not only what we do for the community, but for what we stand for,' he said. On Friday, the company said it even wanted to boost the numbers of participants in its corporate leadership program.
webReference.title: Whittier Daily News

Avon Regional Vice President Garth Warner appeared Friday, September 23, on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show."Warner told the popular entertainer and her audience about Avon's $250,000 contribution to Hurricane Katrina relief, and presented a $100,000 check from Avon for DeGeneres' own Hurrican Katrina efforts.

Jen Brehm of LaserAway

Service Business

We Spoke to Jen Brehm of LaserAway About How to Build a Successful Service Business

As part of my series about the "5 Things You Need To Know To Create a Successful Service Business," I had the pleasure of interviewing Jen Brehm who has been in the aesthetics business for the last decade.
Brehm brings strategic planning and deep cross-selling services expertise in her role as the Executive Vice President at LaserAway, the nation's leader in Aesthetic Dermatology.
She oversees millions of dollars of transactions across the United States with over 500 sales associates.
LaserAway's expansion initiatives have provided Jen with the foundation for her success, establishing new territories nationwide.
Her ability to have a keen eye for talent plays a large part in a rapidly growing organization.
Jen prides herself on building teams that foster the LaserAway culture and brand.

webReference.description:
Lisa Edwards, Benefit's vice president of boutiques, could hardly contain her excitement about it at a recent VIP launch party at the Plaza store.
In fact, she's pretty stoked about the brand's expansion in Texas as a whole.

"Benefit will open many boutiques in the state of Texas," she says, adding that there will be additional outposts in Dallas and Fort Worth, as well as Houston.

The Plano store will be a lot like the one at the Plaza at Preston Center, offering the full assortment of cosmetics (including the beloved Benetint), signature Brow Bar, bronzing and waxing.
Edwards says the Shops at Legacy is a good fit for the brand.

"Legacy has a welcoming neighborhood feel, from the local shops to the larger brands scattered throughout the plaza," she says.
"It is a place where women can come and get everything on their list in one shot.
This is similar to locations that we have all over the country."

Edwards adds that Dallas was the obvious market to launch Texas.

"It is a place where women can come and get everything on their list in one shot.
This is similar to locations that we have all over the country."

Edwards adds that Dallas was the obvious market to launch Texas.

John Longfield-Smith

John Longfield-Smith
John Longfield-Smith is the Vice President of Business Development for The ARCO Group....

John Longfield-Smith
Vice President of Business Development

John Longfield-Smith

John Longfield-Smith is the Vice President of Business Development for The ARCO Group.
He joined ARCO in 2014, bringing more than 20 years of technology industry leadership, computer hardware and software expertise, and executive management experience to his role with the company.

Mr. Longfield-Smith oversees the corporate direction and strategy for ARCO's product and service offerings, including sales support, consulting, marketing, alliances, and channels.
He focuses on strategy, leadership, innovation, and customers.
Says Mr. Longfield-Smith, "Our role as a company is to help our customers save money and innovate."

Before joining ARCO, Mr. Longfield-Smith served as Director of Health Information Technology at McKesson, where his focus on customers, innovation, improved operational efficiency, and execution led to significant growth.
Prior to that, he was CEO of Correctional Health Management, an IT and services company providing back office solutions to the Federal Bureau of Prisons and private correctional healthcare companies.
Mr. Longfield-Smith has extensive experience in operations, sales, and marketing roles with several local start-ups.
He is skilled at leading successful efforts to improve operational efficiency, strengthen the product lines, and drive growth.

Since joining ARCO, Mr. Longfield-Smith has worked to share ARCO's strategy and vision with customers, partners, and the ARCO team.
"Our strategy is to provide a robust set of core services that benefit all of our customers, while leveraging our investments in technology to offer new solutions previously unavailable to small and mid-sized companies," he says.
"We vertically integrate our best-of-breed solutions for performance and a lower cost-of-ownership benefit to provide differentiation.
We want to give our customers choices for how they utilize and access technology-on premises, in a private cloud, using a public cloud, or a hybrid cloud combination.
We provide a choice on how best to access all of this technology."

Schwarzkopf & Henkel

Paul De Bruecker was named Senior Vice President and General Manager of Schwarzkopf & Henkel, a division of Henkel Consumer Goods Inc., in August 2005.

Paul has more than 15 years of international sales and marketing experience with Henkel.
Prior to his current position, he was General Manager of Schwarzkopf & Henkel in Vienna, Austria; Marketing Director and Key Account Director for Schwarzkopf & Henkel in D??????sseldorf, Germany; and a Marketing Director for Schwarzkopf & Henkel in Moscow, Russia.

Prior to joining Henkel in 1989, Paul spent a year in audit at Arthur Andersen in Brussels.
He is a native of Brussels, Belgium and is a 1987 graduate of the Solvay Business School, Universite Libre de Bruxelles.

Home / Staff / Board / June Nwabara

June Nwabara, North America Senior Director of Operations, Merry Maids - ServiceMaster

June is currently the North America Senior Director of Operations for Merry Maids-Servicemaster.
She volunteers with numerous organizations throughout TN including but not limited to Hands on Nashville, National Civil Rights Museum, and Habitat for Humanity.

Before Merry Maids, June served three years as the Regional Director of Operations at Dollar General.

June was Nominated for 2017 Rookie of the Year as a top-performing Regional Director of Operations.

Before Dollar General, June was a nine year partner at Starbucks Coffee Company and served as Regional Director of Operations.
She led store operations within TN overseeing 92 stores.
She managed a team of district managers to create and maintain the Starbucks Experience for partners and customers.

Prior to joining Starbucks, June spent thirteen years with Darden Restaurants and held numerous positions including General Manager, Divisional Training Manager and Director of Operations.
She restored profitability and success to several restaurants and reduced turnover through improved consistency of caring and fairness principles in personnel practices.
As GM, she was one of fourteen chosen to sit on the President's Council.
June holds a Bachelor of Arts degree in Journalism from Michigan State University.
She currently serves on the Executive Board of Directors with Hands on Nashville . In her spare time, she enjoys spending time with her family , friends, and chocolate lab named Lucky, traveling, sampling food and wine pairs while exploring breathtaking locations.
